{{Infobox officeholder | name = Nicolae Petrescu-Comnen | image = Atatürk, Stojadinović, Metaxas, Comnen. Ankara, March 1938 (Koncern Ilustrowany Kurier Codzienny).png | imagesize = 300px | caption = Comnen (on the far-right) at a [[Balkan Pact]] summit in [[Ankara]], March 1938; also pictured: [[Kemal Atatürk]], [[Milan Stojadinović]], [[Ioannis Metaxas]]. | order = [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Romania)|Foreign Minister of Romania]] | term_start = May 1938 | term_end = January 31, 1939 | monarch = [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]] | premier = [[Miron Cristea]] | order2 = Member of the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly of Deputies]] | term_start2 = November 1919 | term_end2 = May 1920 | order3 = | term_start3 = March 1922 | term_end3 = July 10, 1923 | constituency3 = [[Durostor County]] | party = ''[[Independent politician|independent]]'' | otherparty =[[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]] | birth_date = August 24, 1881 | birth_place = [[Bucharest]], [[Kingdom of Romania]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1958|12|8|1881|8|24|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Florence]], [[Italy]] | nationality = [[Romania]]n | profession = Diplomat, academic, poet | nickname = ''Petrescu-Quand même'' | spouse = Antoinette von Benedek }} '''Nicolae Petrescu-Comnen''' ({{IPA-ro|nikoˈla.e peˈtresku komˈnen}}; [[Francization|Gallicized]] as '''Petresco-Comnène''', '''Petrescu-Comnène''' or '''N. P. Comnène''', born '''Nicolae Petrescu'''; August 24, 1881 – December 8, 1958) was a [[Romania]]n diplomat, politician and social scientist, who served as [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Romania)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] in the [[Miron Cristea]] cabinet (between May 1938 and January 31, 1939). He debuted in France as a public lecturer and author of several books on political history, then returned to Romania as a judge and member of the [[University of Bucharest]] faculty. Comnen spent most of World War I in Switzerland, earning respect at home and abroad for his arguments in favor of [[Romanian nationalism|nationalism]], his publicizing of the [[Greater Romania]]n cause, and especially for his support of the Romanian community in [[Dobruja]]. During the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]], he was dispatched to [[Hungarian Republic (1919–20)|Hungary]], proposing political settlements that would have made the [[Treaty of Trianon]] more palatable to Hungarian conservatives. Also noted as an eccentric who published poetry, he was often ridiculed for his claim to a [[Byzantine bureaucracy and aristocracy|Byzantine aristocratic]] descent from the [[Komnenos]].
Comnen returned to serve briefly in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Romanian Assembly of Deputies]], during which time he became a prominent anti-socialist. He was a [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal]] and close to that party's leadership, before embarking on a full-time diplomatic career, originally as Romania's envoy to Switzerland and to the [[League of Nations]] (1923–1927). He had a steady climb during the early interwar, with alternating missions in [[Weimar Republic|Weimar Germany]] and at the [[Holy See]]. His activity centered on debilitating [[Hungarian irredentism]], and, progressively, on the easing of tensions between Romania and the [[Soviet Union]]. As Romania's ambassador to [[Nazi Germany]], Comnen preserved a neutralist line, recognizing Romania's dependence on German industry while seeking to expand cooperation with France and Britain.
Comnen was assigned to lead Foreign Affairs during the early stages of [[King of the Romanians|King]] [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]]'s authoritarian regime. His ministerial term was highly turbulent, overlapping with the expansion of Nazi power, Western [[appeasement]], and a sudden deterioration of [[Romania–Russia relations|Romanian–Soviet relations]]. Comnen recognized the ''[[Anschluss]]'', helped "liquidate" the [[Second Italo-Ethiopian War|Abyssinian question]], and tried to obtain guarantees from Romania's hostile neighbors at [[Bled agreement (1938)|Bled]] and [[Salonika Agreement|Salonika]]. A full crisis followed the [[Munich Agreement]], during which Comnen worked to preserve both a [[Second Czechoslovak Republic|Czechoslovakian state]] and the [[Little Entente]]. He tacitly gave the [[Soviet Air Forces]] access to Romania's airspace, and refused to participate in a partition of [[Carpathian Ruthenia]].
Comnen was ultimately deposed by Carol—allegedly, because he had questioned the king's rationale for repressing the rival [[Iron Guard]]—and replaced with [[Grigore Gafencu]]. Again dispatched to the Holy See, he was sacked by a [[National Legionary State|Guardist government]] after Carol's downfall in 1940. He never returned home, but remained in [[Florence]], a supporter of the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] and agent of the [[Romanian National Committee]]. As such, Comnen worked with Gafencu in the diaspora movement against [[Communist Romania]]. Earning accolades for his new contributions as a humanitarian, he published works of recollections and studies in diplomatic history. In his last years before his death in Florence, he had turned to promoting a [[pan-European identity]].
==Biography== ===Early life=== Nicolae Petrescu was born in [[Bucharest]] on August 24, 1884, the son of a public servant (or magistrate) and his schoolteacher wife.<ref>Petrescu, p. 331; Vițalaru, p. 347</ref><ref name="Constantinide">{{ro icon}} [[Noti Constantinide]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926234817/http://www.memoria.ro/?location=view_article&id=781&from_name=cautare&from=bG9jYXRpb249c2VhcmNoJmtleXdvcmRzPXBldHJlc2N1LWNvbW5lbiZ4PTAmeT0w ''Amintiri''], at ''Memoria.ro''</ref> Baptized [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian Orthodox]],<ref>Vițalaru, p. 348</ref> he was part-[[Greeks in Romania|Greek]]: his maternal grandmother, Ecaterina, was the last descendant of the Greek family Comninò.<ref>Potra, p. 607</ref> Also through his mother, hailing from the Cernovodeanu clan, the future diplomat belonged to the [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|boyar nobility]],<ref>Mihai Sorin Rădulescu, "Sur l'aristocratie roumaine de l'entre-deux-guerres", in ''The New Europe College Yearbook 1996–1997''. p. 352. Bucharest: New Europe College, 2000. {{ISBN|973-98624-4-6}}</ref> and was an uncle of the historian Dan Cernovodeanu.<ref name="mdsbm99–100">Mihai Demetriade, Silviu B. Moldovan, "Ion Mitucă, de la rezistență la disidență", in ''Caietele CNSAS'', Nr. 2/2008, pp. 99–100</ref> His collaborator and subordinate [[Noti Constantinide]] further argues that Petrescu was of [[Roma minority in Romania|Romany]] descent, "a true, purebred, Gypsy" and "highly unusual character".<ref name="Constantinide"/> Having studied at the [[University of Bucharest]] and the [[University of Paris]],<ref name="Constantinide"/> he took a doctorate in Law and Political Science at the latter, and began his career as an [[Ilfov County]] judge in 1906. He worked as a lawyer from 1911 to 1916, while also teaching economics at Bucharest University.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 331–333; Potra, p. 607. See also Rostovsky & Forter, p. 317; Vițalaru, p. 347</ref> He was at the center of political life from his Paris years, when he joined the Romanian Students' Circle. He lectured with the latter at Voltaire Coffeehouse, appearing alongside some of the country's future statesmen and scholars: [[Nicolae Titulescu]], [[Ion G. Duca]], [[Dimitrie Drăghicescu]], and [[Toma Dragu]].<ref>Liliana Beu, "Câteva repere privind originile și familia omului politic I. G. Duca", in ''Buridava'', Vol. V, 2007, p. 138</ref>
[[File:(Petrescu-)Comnen family coat of arms.svg|thumb|200px|Coat of arms used by Petrescu-Comnen]] During that period, he changed his surname to ''Petrescu-Comnen'', thus claiming lineage from the [[Komnenos]] family of [[List of Byzantine Emperors|Byzantine Emperors]] (he also claimed to be related to the [[House of Bonaparte|Bonapartes]]).<ref name="Constantinide"/> The change was made official by his father in 1903, and later backed by a questionable family tree and heraldry, but recognized during his induction into the [[Sacred Military Constantinian Order of Saint George]].<ref>Petrescu, pp. 331–332</ref><ref name="ift126">Sorin Iftimi, ''Vechile blazoane vorbesc. Obiecte armoriate din colecții ieșene'', p. 126. Iași: Palatul Culturii, 2014. {{ISBN|978-606-8547-02-2}}</ref> Petrescu's views on his family's heritage were a frequent topic of ridicule among foreign diplomats (puns on his name included the French-language ''Petrescu-Quand même''—"Petrescu-All the Same", and the generic "Nicolae Perhaps-Comnen").<ref name="Constantinide"/><ref>Vițalaru, p. 348</ref> Historian [[Andrei Pippidi]] sees the Byzantine claim as entirely spurious, "snobbish", "unjustly decreasing the value of [his] character."<ref name="apcasă">{{ro icon}} [[Andrei Pippidi]], [http://dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/bordeie-si-obiceie/articol/o-casa-de-ministru "SOS București. O casă de ministru"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Nr. 393, August 2011</ref> Genealogist Dumitru Năstase proposes that the Petrescus were in fact only attached to the village of [[Prundu|Comeni]], a name later corrupted into ''Comneni'', then ''Comnen''.<ref name="ift126"/> The "bewildering" Byzantine pedigree was also ridiculed by the left-wing satirist [[Petre Pandrea]], who noted that, beyond his "princely obsession", Comnen was a "fundamentally decent man."<ref name="pandr">{{ro icon}} [[Petre Pandrea]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20111223105651/http://atelier.liternet.ro/articol/9729/Petre-Pandrea/Brancusi-Pravila-de-la-Craiova.html ''Brâncuși. Pravila de la Craiova'' (fragment)], Atelier LiterNet, August 18, 2010</ref>
Comnen's early work included poetry: in July 1904, his patriotic [[ode]] to [[Iosif Vulcan]] was carried by the magazine ''[[Familia (magazine)|Familia]]''.<ref>"Homagiu marelui român Vulcan", in ''[[Familia (magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 25–26, 1904, p. 303</ref> According to Constantinide, young Petrescu authored a volume of poems which he signed as ''Petrescu-[[D'Artagnan]]''.<ref name="Constantinide"/> He is known to have published, as Petresco-Comnène, the collection ''Il était une fois'' ("Once upon a Time", 1904). Comprising [[Parnassianism|Parnassian]] verse,<ref>Petrescu, p. 331</ref> it received a lukewarm review from the staff critic at ''[[Le Figaro]]'': "the work of a real poet", it nevertheless contained "pages that are quite needlessly bizarre".<ref>Philippe-Emmanuel Glaser, "Petite Chronique des Lettres", in ''[[Le Figaro]]'', April 15, 1904, p. 3</ref> For a while, this aspect of his literary activity merged with his scholarly work. On June 4, 1905, ''[[Le Journal du Dimanche]]'' noted his "strange conference" about [[Albert Samain]], which ended with readings from Samain's works by a group of actresses.<ref>Sales, "La Semaine Dramatique", in ''[[Le Journal du Dimanche]]'', No. 3340, June 1905, p. 365</ref>
Comnen also contributed a study of early Romanian jurisprudence (1902), and a monograph on the [[history of the Jews in Romania]] (1905). The latter earned him the [[Romanian Academy]]'s [[Ion Heliade Rădulescu]] award, and special praise from the scholar [[A. D. Xenopol]].<ref>Petrescu, p. 331</ref> He continued in the fields of law and sociology, with a succession of tracts and lectures: ''Ziua de 8 ore de muncă'' ("The 8-hour Day", 1906), ''Accidente profesionale'' ("Work-related Accidents", 1907), ''Câteva considerațiuni asupra socialismului și asupra roadelor sale'' ("Some Musings on Socialism and Its Results", 1909), ''Studiu asupra intervențiunii statului între capital și muncă'' ("A Review of State Intervention between Capital and Labor", 1910).<ref>Petrescu, pp. 332–333; Vițalaru, p. 347</ref> These contributions detail Comnen's take on the [[Labor movement in Romania|local labor movement]], showing him as a [[social liberalism|social liberal]] who fully embraced unionization.<ref>Victor Rizescu, "De la emanciparea muncii la protecția socială: politica reprezentării profesionale în România la începutul secolului XX", in ''Polis'', Issue 4 (14), 2016, pp. 178, 179</ref> ''Câteva considerațiuni'' was awarded another Academy prize, and again received a good review from Xenopol.<ref>Petrescu, p. 332</ref>
Although Petrescu showed himself to be staunchly against [[Hungarian nationalism]], his wife, Antoinette von Benedek,<ref name="apcasă"/><ref name="LFmar">E. Delaroche, "Le Monde & la Ville. Mariages", in ''[[Le Figaro]]'', August 4, 1912, p. 3</ref><ref name="mhill">"Roumanian {{sic}} Art at Maryhill", in ''The Othello Outlook'', March 25, 1998, p. 3</ref> may have been of [[Hungarians in Romania|Hungarian]] origin—allegedly, he had her adopted by an impoverished count in [[Trieste]], as a means for the family to inherit a formal title.<ref name="Constantinide"/> Other sources simply list her as a Triestine [[Austrians|Austrian]].<ref>Pavlowitch, p. 240</ref> They were married on August 4, 1912, at the [[Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, Paris|Russian Cathedral of Paris]].<ref name="LFmar"/> The couple already had a son, Raymond-Alexis, born 1908, and a daughter, Elsa-Irène, born 1909.<ref>Vițalaru, p. 348</ref> According to Pandrea, neither of the Comnen children shared their father's "obsession". He described both as "my friends", "sensible, unpretentious kids".<ref name="pandr"/>
===World War I and aftermath=== Petrescu-Comnen's career took an upward turn after [[Romania in World War I|Romania entered World War I]], initially as a noted campaigner for the cause of [[Greater Romania]]; he was also tasked with explaining [[Treaty of Bucharest (1918)|Romania's capitulation]]. According to Duca, Comnen, "whose precarious health had exiled to Switzerland", matched and surpassed Drăghicescu's similar work in France. He displayed "exquisite skills as a propagandist".<ref name="igd144">[[Ion G. Duca]], ''Amintiri politice, II'', p. 144. Munich: Jon Dumitru-Verlag, 1981</ref> Initially, Comnen contributed to the cause from a Swiss sanitarium, where he was recovering, hoping to carry forward the work of his deceased friend, [[Aurel Popovici]]. With articles in ''Le Genevois'', and with tracts such as ''Notes sur la guerre roumaine'' ("Notes on the Romanian War"), he complained about the [[Allies of World War I|Entente Powers]] "sacrificing Romania" after the [[October Revolution]].<ref>Petrescu, p. 333</ref> French scholar Marcel Emerit found his a biased, "unilateral", perspective, containing "a lively condemnation" of the [[Russian Republic]].<ref>Marcel Emerit, "Partie bibliographique. II. Autour de la guerre. Pétain (général), ''Le Drame roumain (1916–1918)''", in ''[[Revue d'Histoire Moderne]]'', Vol. 8, Issue 6, 1933, p. 512</ref> Comnen also contributed an ethnographic overview of [[Dobruja]] (''La Dobrogea''), just as the region was being absorbed into a [[Greater Bulgaria]]. [[Georges Lacour-Gayet]], who presented the work at the [[Romanian Academy]], noted that the "savant work" of "truth and justice", had exposed the practices of [[Bulgarization]].<ref>[[Georges Lacour-Gayet]], "Rapports verbaux et communications diverses. ''La Dobrogea (Dobroudja)'', de M. N. P. Comnène", in ''Séances et Travaux de l'Académie des Sciences Morales. Comptes Rendus'', Vol. 78, Issue 7, 1918, pp. 404–405</ref>
Comnen received international attention, as well as collaborations from [[Emil Isac]], [[Constantin Flondor]], and [[Ghiță Popp]].<ref>Petrescu, pp. 333–334</ref> He also approached the [[Czechoslovak National Council]] and established a working relationship with [[Edvard Beneš]].<ref name="igd144"/> Eventually settling with his family in [[Bern]],<ref>Petrescu, p. 333</ref> but was delegated to [[Geneva]] by [[Prime Minister of Romania|Prime Minister]] [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]], and was later one of Romania's envoys to the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]]. While in Paris, he published the bilingual atlas ''Roumania through the Ages. La terre roumaine a travers les âges''.<ref>Petrescu, p. 333</ref> It was at this time that he became the target of criticism from the far left—communist writer [[Panait Istrati]], who also resided in Switzerland, alleged that Brătianu's delegates [[Vasile Lucaciu]] and Petrescu-Comnen were demagogues, preparing the annexation of [[Transylvania]] to the "[[satrap]] yoke" of the [[Kingdom of Romania|Romanian Kingdom]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Mircea Iorgulescu]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20071008065758/http://www.revista22.ro/html/index.php?art=626&nr=2003-10-07 "Istrati în Elveția (II)"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 708, September–October 2003</ref> Petrescu-Comnen's input was valued by the Transylvanian delegate, [[Alexandru Vaida-Voevod]], who kept him as an adviser during meetings with [[Robert Lansing]]. By then, Comnen had befriended Lansing's nephew, [[Allen Dulles]].<ref>Petrescu, pp. 333–334</ref>
At this stage, the collapse of [[Austria-Hungary]] had ensured the [[union of Transylvania with Romania]]; it also sparked a [[Hungarian–Romanian War]], in which Romania faced a [[Hungarian Soviet Republic]]. According to Comnen's own account, he met with a deputation of Hungarian conservatives and liberals, including [[Gyula Andrássy the Younger|Count Andrássy]], [[Alfred III, Prince of Windisch-Grätz|Alftred Windisch-Grätz]] and [[Mihály Károlyi]], who demanded that Romania back their anti-communist government, based in [[Szeged]], and provide support to the "White Guards".<ref name="uscăt">{{es icon}} Jorge Uscătescu, [http://hemeroteca.sevilla.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1957/03/16/013.html "Primera derrota del comunismo"], in ''[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC de Sevilla]]'', March 16, 1957, p. 13</ref> In August 1919, Comnen was contacted by another delegation, representing the [[Hungarian Republic (1919–20)|Hungarian Republic]]. Comprising [[István Bethlen]], [[Miklós Bánffy]], and [[Pál Teleki]], it asked for Transylvania to be recognized as a federal entity of the Romanian state.<ref>Major, p. 153</ref>
In September, the [[Artur Văitoianu]] cabinet, with support from [[Iuliu Maniu]],<ref>Petrescu, p. 334</ref> sent Comnen on mission to Hungary, where he also ledd the Romanian press office.<ref>Potra, p. 607</ref> This experience, in the aftermath of the Soviet Republic, acquainted Petrescu with communism (as detailed by his memoir, published 1957).<ref name="uscăt"/><ref>Petrescu, pp. 334, 352; Vițalaru, p. 347</ref> Residing at [[Hotel Gellért]] in [[Budapest]], he left the city with the lifting of Romanian occupation in October 1919. As a hostile [[Royal Hungarian Army|National Army]] moved in, he still expressed his belief that [[Hungary–Romania relations]] would be mended and preserved.<ref>Radu Cosmin, ''Românii la Budapesta, II. În capitala lui Bella Kuhn'', p. 341. Bucharest: Editura Librăriei Stănciulescu, 1920. {{OCLC|431185998}}</ref> At the time, he was secretly approached by Bánffy to discuss "reconciliation between the Hungarian and Romanian peoples".<ref>Major, p. 134</ref> Comnen later claimed that he had also reached a friendly agreement with Count Andrássy and other Hungarian conservatives, but that this had been vetoed by Maniu.<ref name="uscăt"/><ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VI'', p. 223</ref> If accepted, the Hungarian proposal would have led to the establishment of a [[dual monarchy]]; [[Ferdinand I of Romania|Ferdinand I]], [[King of the Romanians]], would have also reigned as Ferdinand VI [[King of Hungary|of Hungary]].<ref name="uscăt"/>
Petrescu-Comnen soon joined the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL), and, in the [[Romanian general election, 1919|November 1919 election]], he won a [[Durostor County]] seat in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly of Deputies]].<ref>Petrescu, p. 334; Vițalaru, p. 347</ref> He had little connection with his constituency, but was selected by the local party chapter because of his good reputation as an advocate of Dobrujan Romanians.<ref>Petrescu, p. 334</ref> He only took his seat in 1920, when he returned from Paris,<ref name="ic25">Ion Constantinescu, "«Domnilor, vă stricați sănătatea degeaba...»", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', July 1971, p. 25</ref> and was again reelected [[Romanian general election, 1922|in March 1922]]); throughout these separate terms, he was active on [[Parliament of Romania|Parliament]]'s Foreign Policy Commission.<ref>Vițalaru, p. 347. See also Potra, p. 607</ref> Vaida-Voevod was Prime Minister of a coalition cabinet formed by the [[Romanian National Party]], the [[Peasants' Party (Romania)|Peasants' Party]], and the [[Democratic Nationalist Party (Romania)|Democratic Nationalists]]. Petrescu-Comnen spearheaded the PNL opposition, especially so during March 1920, when he filibustered against the appointment of [[Nicolae L. Lupu]] as [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Romania)|Interior Minister]].<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, II'', pp. 349–350</ref> He was also noted for proposing legislation that made striking illegal, pressuring the Vaida-Voevod cabinet to look into allegations of [[Bolshevik]] influence inside the [[Socialist Party of Romania]]. Despite PNL protests and support from the far-right [[National-Christian Defense League]], Petrescu's law was not passed.<ref name="ic25"/> A disappointed Vaida-Voevod claimed that, with his new career in Parliament, Petrescu had "sacrificed himself" to Brătianu's "politicking".<ref>Petrescu, p. 334</ref>
===Geneva and Weimar Republic=== Still active in diplomacy, Petrescu-Comnen had enjoyed a friendly rapport with the [[Second Polish Republic|Polish Republic]] and, in 1920, had played a role in negotiating the [[Polish-Romanian Alliance]].<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, II'', pp. 364–365</ref> From 1922 to 1927, he was also a perennial Romanian delegate to the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO).<ref>Potra, p. 608</ref> On July 10, 1923, he was named ambassador to Bern, and, in August of that year, also became delegate to the [[League of Nations]];<ref>Petrescu, p. 335; Vițalaru, pp. 347, 348</ref> according to Constantinide, he owed this appointment to his political connections.<ref name="Constantinide"/> He followed with concern the [[Locarno Treaties]], which signaled a normalization of relations with the [[Weimar Republic]], and as such the ominous rise of a new Germany. He wanted Romania to align herself with the anti-League [[Kingdom of Italy]] as a safeguard, personally befriending [[Benito Mussolini]] and [[Dino Grandi]] during ILO meetings.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 335–336</ref> He worked with representatives of both Poland and [[Lithuania]] against a hostile [[Soviet Union]], which they viewed as a [[rogue state]]. When the latter would not adhere to the Convention for the Control of the Trade in Arms and Ammunition, Comnen, [[Kazimierz Sosnkowski]] and [[Dovas Zaunius]] introduced their own opt-out objections to the Convention.<ref>David R. Stone, "Imperialism and Sovereignty: The League of Nations' Drive to Control the Global Arms Trade", in ''[[Journal of Contemporary History]]'', Vol. 35, Issue 2, April 2000, pp. 227–230</ref>
Alongside [[Nicolae Titulescu]], who took over his seat at the League of Nations, Comnen worked to convince the Entente that Greater Romania was respecting her [[Minorities of Romania|ethnic minorities]]. One effort, which also involved [[Constantin Angelescu]] and [[Alexandru C. Constantinescu]], involved a defense of Romania's educational programs, confronting propaganda by [[Albert Apponyi]] and the "Hungarian bishops".<ref>Potra, pp. 72–78</ref> Titulescu and Comnen made a poor impression with British diplomats by producing blunt threats, such as announcing that Romania would individually sue all Hungarian colonists still present in the [[Banat]].<ref>Miklós Zeidler, "The League of Nations and Hungarian Minority Petitions", in Ferenc Eiler, Dagmar Hájková (eds.), ''Czech and Hungarian Minority Policy in Central Europe 1918–1938'', p. 100. Prague & Budapest: Masarykův ústav a Archiv Akademie věd České republiky & MTA Etnikai-nemzeti Kisebbségkutató Intézete, 2009. {{ISBN|978-80-86495-54-5}}</ref> However, they convinced the Norwegian inspector [[Erik Colban]] that they were acting in good faith.<ref>Victor Osăceanu, "România versus Ungaria la Societatea Națiunilor", in ''Studii și Articole de Istorie'', Vol. LXXVI, 2010, pp. 56–57</ref> Comnen also called for a negative campaign against the [[Magyar Party (Romania)|Magyar Party]], once the latter had appealed to the League.<ref name="Nastasă"/>
Aware of the issues faced by Romanian Hungarians, Jews and other communities, Comnen showed his concern about what this could effect for Greater Romania's image abroad. In 1924, reporting from the League of Nations, he complained that the new [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)|Kingdom of Hungary]] had a tactical advantage: "it is confident that our situation inside the European concert of nations is shakier than that of [[First Republic of Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovakia]] and [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]], that the situation of minorities is in reality less good than elsewhere, and, finally, that an unfavorable current can be easily determined against us with support from [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russia]], Jews, Catholics and Protestants the world over".<ref name="Nastasă">Lucian Nastasă, "Maghiarii din România și etica minoritară. Repere istorice, 1920–1940", in Lucian Nastasă, Levente Salat (eds.), ''Maghiarii din România și etica minoritară'', p. 37. Cluj-Napoca: Ethnocultural Diversity Resource Center, 2003. {{ISBN|973-86239-1-X}}</ref> In 1924 and again in 1925, he welcomed in Geneva the Romanian politico [[Nicolae Iorga]], who lectured to an international public about [[Balkan]] topics and "imperialism in the Orient".<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, IV'', pp. 131, 222</ref>
Early in 1926, a new National Liberal cabinet proposed Petrescu-Comnen for the post of [[List of Ambassadors from Romania to the United States|Ambassador to the United States]]. He adamantly refused, noting that America was "radically incompatible" with his character;<ref>Petrescu, p. 336</ref> he asked instead to be moved to Rome. In the end, he was dispatched to Berlin, which was considered a very difficult mission, suited for his talents.<ref>Petrescu, p. 336</ref> He served there between February 9, 1927 and May 1937, interrupted by a mandate to the [[Holy See]] (January 1930 – May 1932).<ref name="Constantinide"/><ref>Petrescu, pp. 336–342; Potra, p. 608; Rostovsky & Forter, p. 317; Vițalaru, pp. 347, 348–352</ref> In 1929, Comnen also joined the faculty of [[The Hague Academy of International Law]].<ref>Potra, p. 608</ref>
His main contribution during the Weimar period was a German–Romanian Chamber of Commerce. Entirely his "brainchild", it was established in November 1929 with funds pooled by [[Danatbank]], [[Deutsche Bank]], [[Dresdner Bank]], [[Krupp]], and [[Otto Wolff]].<ref>Stephen G. Gross, ''Export Empire: German Soft Power in Southeastern Europe, 1890–1945'', p. 100. Cambridge etc.: [[Cambridge University Press]], 2015. {{ISBN|978-1-107-53148-2}}</ref> As a partisan of Titulescu's policies, Comnen was in favor of normalizing [[Romania–Russia relations|Romanian–Soviet relations]], attempting to settle the issue of [[Bessarabia]].<ref>Ragsdale & Trommer, p. 55</ref> As early as 1927, he approached [[Maxim Litvinov]], a Soviet diplomat who served as [[Foreign Minister of Russia|Foreign Minister]]. Despite harsh criticism at home over speculations that Romania was dropping her guard, this helped bring about a period of communication between the government of Romania and the Soviets.<ref>Ragsdale & Trommer, pp. 55–57</ref> He also reported that, with backing from [[Gustav Stresemann]], he could solve another major dispute, surrounding the [[Romanian Treasure]], but that his government overseers never let him.<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VI'', p. 223</ref>
Comnen's stint in [[Vatican City]] was prompted by the government reshuffle ordered by Prime Minister Maniu, and disappointed Petrescu-Comnen: he was negotiating an economic treaty with Germany and, moreover, preferred the post of ambassador to Italy.<ref>Vițalaru, p. 349</ref> While in Rome, he was primarily noted for protesting against the apparent rapprochement between the Holy See and Hungary, but also for using his position to guess at Mussolini's external policies.<ref>Petrescu, p. 337</ref> He was responsible for obtaining from [[Pope Pius XI]] a quick recognition of [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]] as [[King of the Romanians]], following the latter's coup, and for ending a long-standing dispute surrounding the corporate status of [[Catholic Church in Romania|Romanian Roman Catholic churches]].<ref>Vițalaru, pp. 349–350</ref>
Comnen's contacts in Vatican City informed him of an imminent Soviet attack on Romania, which is supposedly why Maniu massively increased military spending.<ref>Brînzeu, p. 332</ref> The latter part of his term coincided with Iorga's premiership: Petrescu-Comnen advised the cabinet not to engage in "violent and hasty" actions against the Hungarian Catholic clergy, while personally ensuring cooperation between the state and the [[Romanian Greek Catholic Church|Greek-Rite Catholics]].<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VI'', pp. 206, 220–221</ref> According to Iorga, he was supporting the King and the government, including against the PNL, boasting that he had stopped a PNL propaganda campaign abroad.<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VI'', p. 221</ref> His dealings with the Holy See were opposed by rival [[Onisifor Ghibu]], who claimed that Petrescu-Comnen was a disgrace to his office.<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VI'', p. 392</ref>
===Ambassador to Nazi Germany=== Even from Italy, Petrescu-Comnen closely observed the [[Great Depression]] and the decline of the Weimar Republic. Already in 1931, while vacationing in [[Brittany]], he had predicted that Germany would fall to communism.<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VI'', p. 153</ref> His return to Berlin was facilitated by Carol II, who complained that the outgoing ambassador, [[Gheorghe Tașcă]], was "nonexistent".<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VI'', pp. 311, 355</ref> The establishment of a [[Nazi Germany|Nazi regime]] came as a surprise. Petrescu-Comnen was prudent in his contacts with the Nazis, and his diplomatic notes of the time were ambivalent.<ref name="Constantinide"/><ref>Petrescu, pp. 337–341; {{ro icon}} [[Victor Neumann]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/articol/diplomatia-romaniei-fata-in-fata-cu-reich-ul-nazist/ "Diplomația României față în față cu Reich-ul nazist"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 60, April 2001; Vițalaru, pp. 350–351</ref> Former Prime Minister Iorga, who remained friends with Comnen, records that Comnen thought [[Adolf Hitler]] "naive and sincere, still learning the ropes."<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VII'', p. 197</ref>
During 1934, Comnen was hoping to drive a wedge between [[German re-armament]] and [[Hungarian irredentism]], approaching various factions represented in the [[Hitler Cabinet]]. In May, he invited [[Ioan Lupaș]] of the Romanian Anti-Revisionist League to lecture in Berlin about minority religions in Romania.<ref>Alexandru Mareș, "Liga antirevizionistă română și iredentismul", in ''Studii și Articole de Istorie'', Vol. LXXVI, 2010, p. 70</ref> Later that year, he and consul [[Constantin Karadja]] obtained from [[Hermann Göring]] a guarantee that Germany would not go to war over Hungary—but this pledge was quickly dismissed by [[Konstantin von Neurath]] and [[Alfred Rosenberg]].<ref>Potra, pp. 209–210, 311–313; Rosenberg ''et al.'', pp. 60–62</ref> Rosenberg was persuaded that Comnen, a "Titulescu representative", was lying, and began maneuvering to have him recalled.<ref>Potra, p. 210; Rosenberg ''et al.'', pp. 62, 108</ref> Comnen's Russian policy was soon restored by the apparent upset in German–Soviet relations and the [[Franco-Soviet Treaty of Mutual Assistance]].<ref>Petrescu, pp. 338, 339–340</ref> He preferred this realignment to the Nazi alternative: his notes of 1936 show him alarmed by the "antisemitic objective" of Nazism (accurately predicting a ''[[Kristallnacht]]''), by the regime's [[Nazi persecution of the Catholic Church in Germany|public anti-Catholicism]], and overall by the "nebulous criteria of German law".<ref>Petrescu, pp. 340–341</ref>
Although he viewed the [[1936 Winter Olympics|Winter]] and [[1936 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]] as propaganda, Comnen accepted the Olympics Cross, First Class from Hitler.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 341, 354</ref> Over the following months, the rise of the fascist [[Iron Guard]] and the [[Romanian general election, 1937|problematic elections of December 1937]] upset the liberal order in Romania. In the run-up to the elections, Comnen had sought to mitigate Germany's open support for the Iron Guard, offering its government a chance to apologize for [[Wilhelm Fabricius|Ambassador Fabricius]]' presence at the [[funerals of Ion Moța and Vasile Marin]]. This request was angrily rejected in Berlin, mainly because the ambassador "had only attended a religious ceremony".<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VII'', p. 402</ref> Eventually, Carol pleased Germany by handing government to [[Octavian Goga]] and his Nazi-oriented [[National Christian Party]] (PNC). Comnen confirmed to this standard, communicating in Berlin the guidelines of Romania's neutralist policy: preservation of [[France–Romania relations|Franco–]] and [[Romania–United Kingdom relations|British–Romanian relations]], full economic cooperation with Germany, and "no hostile attitude toward Russia."<ref>Cristian-Alexandru Boghian, "The Management of Romania's Communication with Germany, Italy and the USSR in the Context of Octavian Goga's Government (1937–1938)", in ''Communication, Context and Interdisciplinarity'', Vol. 3, 2015, p. 317</ref>
Comnen went on to serve as undersecretary of the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Romania)|Foreign Affairs Ministry]], which was led by [[Gheorghe Tătărescu]]. His advancement was supposed to placate Germany, which had been unpleasantly surprised by the PNC's downfall; it was also greeted by the Italian ambassador, [[Ugo Sola]].<ref>Vițalaru, p. 351. See also Pavlowitch, p. 240</ref> He was described in the ''[[Journal des Débats]]'' as primarily a [[Francophile]],<ref>Vițalaru, p. 351</ref> but continued to be seen by the ''[[Federal Foreign Office|Auswärtiges Amt]]'' as a friend of Germany in the cabinet, on par with [[Alexandru Averescu]] and [[Constantin Argetoianu]].<ref>Arhire, p. 293</ref> Upon his recall to Bucharest, Hitler showed his appreciation for the diplomat in a special letter to Carol II—this was a first in Romanian annals.<ref>Petrescu, p. 342</ref> Soon after taking office, Comnen, who was more probably a neutralist,<ref>Arhire, p. 293; Prisăcaru, p. 181</ref> presided upon the council of the [[Balkan Pact]], and, in February 1938, drafted its [[Ankara]] resolution, condemning "any interference in the internal politics" of member states.<ref>Petrescu, p. 342</ref>
===Ministerial term=== ====''Anschluss'' and Munich Crisis==== During the early days of 1938, Comnen announced that he was no longer involved with the National Liberal Party, taking his distance from Tătărescu.<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VII'', p. 462</ref> Widely tipped to become the full minister, he took over on March 30, days after the ''[[Anschluss]]'' crisis.<ref>Petrescu, p. 342</ref> His term coincided with the major developments in Carol's feud with the Iron Guard; Prime Minister [[Miron Cristea]] served Carol's own authoritarian regime, which consolidated a single-party [[National Renaissance Front]]. One of Comnen's first actions was to inform the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office|British Foreign Office]] and the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Development (France)|French Foreign Ministry]] about Germany's economic tactics; he also advised Germany not to act against Czechoslovakia, or risk a "world war".<ref>Petrescu, pp. 342–343</ref> Comnen also emphasized the importance of Franco–British–Romanian relations by elevating the ranks of his ambassadors in both countries, and by making Tătărescu his Paris envoy.<ref>Pavlowitch, p. 241</ref> However, Romania was facing international criticism over her disbanding of the [[Internationalization of the Danube River|Danube Commission]] and her introduction of [[Antisemitic laws in Romania|antisemitic laws]].<ref>Petrescu, p. 346</ref> Her relations with Britain were also strained by the appointment of [[Edward Wood, 1st Earl of Halifax|Lord Halifax]], a proponent of [[appeasement]] and thus "great friend of Hitlerian Germany", as [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]].<ref>Pop, p. 124</ref>
The situation was complicated by a sudden worsening of relations with the Soviet Union, when the Soviet diplomat [[Fedor Butenko]] disappeared in Bucharest. Before the details of this escape emerged, the Soviet side was claiming that Butenko had been abducted or killed by a PNC militia, the ''[[Lăncieri]]''. There was a sudden worsening of Romanian–Soviet relations, almost to the brink of war.<ref>Iorga, ''Memorii, VII'', pp. 461–463</ref> Eventually, the investigating team informed Comnen of the actual facts, namely that Butenko had defected of his own free will, to escape a likely execution in the [[Great Purge]]; this was later confirmed in a letter which Butenko addressed to the Romanian Foreign Ministry from his new home in Italy.<ref>Maffei, pp. 541–545</ref> Despite being targeted by Soviet officials, who alleged that he had a role in this affair, he did not speak publicly in support of Butenko.<ref>Maffei, p. 545; Petrescu, p. 346</ref>
Petrescu-Comnen was subject to increasing pressures from the Germans to reorient his country's foreign policy towards the [[Tripartite Pact]]. Rosenberg called on Petrescu-Comnen to abandon Little Entente commitments to Czechoslovakia, as a prerequisite for good economic exchanges with Germany.<ref>Dreyfus, p. 343</ref> The Romanian minister sought to counter such pressures by negotiating an economic treaty with Britain, which was still being discussed, then shelved, in August 1938.<ref>Pop, pp. 124–125</ref> The relations were tested by the question of [[History of the Jews in Romania|Romanian Jewish]] disenfranchisement, with Comnen refusing to accept British suggestions that the policy be reversed.<ref>[http://www.jta.org/1938/05/10/archive/rumania-rejects-compromise-on-citizenship-revision-to-ignore-petitions ''Rumania Rejects Compromise on Citizenship Revision; to Ignore Petitions''], [[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]] release, May 10, 1938</ref> Progressively, Romania was coming to terms with her economic dependency on Germany, with Comnen issuing statements that hinted to a change of priorities in foreign affairs. Romania was therefore quick in recognizing the ''Anschluss'' as "unavoidable"<ref>Arhire, pp. 293–294</ref> and "unobjectionable".<ref>Prisăcaru, pp. 181–182</ref> His ministry still attempted to prioritize Romania's commitment to Czechoslovakia (tested by both Nazi and Polish demands, as well as by Czechoslovakia's friendship towards the Soviet state); it eventually witnessed the [[Munich Agreement]], and, despite official protests, had to seek a new course in European politics.<ref>Arhire, pp. 349–350; Dreyfus, p. 348; Mareș, ''passim''; Petrescu, pp. 343–346; Ragsdale & Trommer, pp. 55, 77–78</ref>
Petrescu-Comnen was reserved about the Soviets' intervention on Czechoslovakia's side; he insisted that Romanian cooperation with the [[Red Army]] would only come with a recognition of Bessarabia as Romanian territory.<ref>Cienciala, p. 96; Petrescu, p. 344</ref> More specifically, Comnen and the rest of his government expected France to provide Romania with guarantees.<ref>Arhire, pp. 349–350; Carley, pp. 59–60</ref> Contacted by [[Maxim Litvinov]] and [[Kamil Krofta]] in September, he promised that he would obtain flyover rights for the [[Soviet Air Forces]], but these were never approved by his government.<ref>Davidson, pp. 202–203</ref> In conversation with [[Georges Bonnet]], he confessed his own fears, namely that Litvinov was preparing the invasion of Bessarabia; he also commented at length on Romania's unpreparedness for war. According to Comnen, Soviet aircraft could cross into Romania's airspace at will, if the Soviets so desired, since it could not ever be hit by Romanian [[flak gun]]s; he also insisted that a Red Army presence in Romania would have been of no service to Czechoslovakia, since roads linking Bessarabia to [[Carpathian Ruthenia]] were few and poorly maintained.<ref>Davidson, p. 203. See also Bregman, p. 308</ref>
By then, Romania's airspace was intensely used by Soviet aircraft. When pressed about this issue by Göring, as [[Ministry of Aviation (Nazi Germany)|Germany's Air Minister]], Comnen insisted that the planes could not be downed.<ref>Moisuc, pp. 290–291</ref> In effect, with his revelations about the flak range, Comnen gave the Soviets a free pass—as noted by French diplomatic cables, he did not want terrestrial passage, but "close[d] his eyes to overflights of [Romania's] territory."<ref>Carley, p. 55</ref> Air defense, Comnen promised, "would take a few badly aimed potshots at Soviet planes, and that would be that."<ref>Carley, p. 60</ref> More officially, in September he also allowed the [[Czechoslovak Air Force]] to fly its newly purchased warplanes from Soviet bases, over Romania.<ref>Prisăcaru, p. 184</ref> Beneš and [[Heliodor Píka]] later testified that Comnen had respected his promises to Czechoslovakia.<ref>Moisuc, p. 291</ref> As argued by journalist Alexander Bregman and historian [[Anna M. Cienciala]], this exposes as false the claims publicized by [[Soviet historiography]], according to which Romania sabotaged the Czechoslovak–Soviet entente. The Soviets, they note, limited their involvement because they were unprepared for war with Germany.<ref>Bregman, pp. 307–309; Cienciala, pp. 96–97</ref> Nevertheless, as argued by historians such as Rebecca Haynes, Comnen himself never prepared for a Romanian military intervention in support of Czechoslovakia, except against an invasion by or from Hungary.<ref>Ionel Sîrbu, "Recenzii. Rebecca Haynes, ''Politica României față de Germania între 1936 și 1940''", in ''Codrul Cosminului'', Issue 10, 2004, p. 306</ref>
====Crumbling alliances==== [[File:Carpathian Ruthenia issue, 1938.svg|thumb|330px|The issue of [[Carpathian Ruthenia]] (or [[Carpatho-Ukraine]]) in 1938: [[Second Czechoslovak Republic|post-Munich Czechoslovakia]] and the other countries of the [[Little Entente]] in blue, with Carpatho-Ukraine shaded; in red, [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)|Hungary]] and her supporter, [[Second Republic of Poland|Poland]]. The region's annexation would have cut off Czechoslovakia's links with all her allies]] In May, at the height of the Munich crisis, Petrescu-Comnen surfaced as a spokesman for the [[Little Entente]] as a whole. He represented it at the League of Nations, where he recognized the [[Italian Ethiopia|Italian annexation of Ethiopia]] as irreversible. He "took the initiative in liquidating the Ethiopian question",<ref>"La journée: Dernières nouvelles. Le problème éthiopien à la Société des Nations", in ''[[Le Temps (Paris)|Le Temps]]'', May 2, 1938, p. 8</ref> then followed the Anglo–French attempt to restore relations with Italy: "the Italian conquest would have to be acknowledged, unless [League members] were prepared to live forever in an unreal world."<ref>"Abyssinia's Fate. Conquest Recognition. Debate at Geneva. British View Favoured", in ''[[The West Australian]]'', May 14, 1938, p. 21</ref> Comnen also hosted the Little Entente leaders at a summit in [[Sinaia]], and agreed to negotiate a collective nonaggression pact with Hungary; he also empowered [[Ioannis Metaxas]] to approach the [[Kingdom of Bulgaria]] for similar talks. He managed to sign accords to that effect (the [[Bled agreement (1938)|Bled]] and [[Salonika Agreement|Salonika agreements]]), despite German pressures on Yugoslavia.<ref>Boisdron, pp. 79–84; Moisuc, pp. 285–286; Petrescu, p. 343</ref> Although celebrated in France as a major achievement for peace and stability, these arrangements were in fact "very banal", and Bled presented no guarantees for Czechoslovakia's survival.<ref>Boisdron, pp. 80–82</ref> They were also notable for lifting the ban on Hungarian re-armament, which he advertised as a prelude to reaching "good terms with Hungary."<ref>Kenéz, p. 6</ref> However, Comnen delayed the application of that clause to October, which reportedly caused [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Hungary)|Hungary's Forign Minister]], [[Kálmán Kánya]], to lose his temper on at least one occasion.<ref>Mareș, pp. 310–311</ref>
Comnen was highly critical of Poland's participation in the [[German occupation of Czechoslovakia]], which upset his plans for resistance. Returning to Geneva as the Little Entente was falling apart, he managed to persuade Yugoslavia's [[Milan Stojadinović]] not to give up on the project. On September 23, they addressed Hungary an ultimatum, threatening war if she would invade Czechoslovakia; Stojadinović rescinded five days later.<ref>Moisuc, pp. 286–287</ref> Comnen continued to press for Yugoslavia to maintain the Little Entente, while also urging [[Jan Syrový]]'s government to reconcile with the Ruthenian autonomists and the [[Slovak People's Party]].<ref>Mareș, pp. 78, 335, 366–368, 377</ref> The same month, he also approached Litvinov, promising that Romania would play no part in "anti-Soviet actions",<ref>Moisuc, p. 292</ref> also renouncing the demand for territorial guarantees, and even proposing that the Red Army be allowed to cross into Carpathian Ruthenia by way of [[Cernăuți County]].<ref>Cienciala, pp. 100–101</ref>
The Polish-Romanian Alliance was also threatened by warm [[Hungary–Poland relations]]. Among the Polish diplomats, Count Leo Orlowski theorized that Romania should join the alliance with Hungary, "a country of the future", and abandon Czechoslovakia.<ref>Mareș, pp. 65, 362–363</ref> At an October conference in [[Galați]], Comnen tried to persuade [[Józef Beck]], the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Poland)|Polish Foreign Minister]], not to accept a Hungarian takeover in Ruthenia. He then refused Polish offers for Romania to annex parts of that region, in [[Northern Maramuresh]].<ref>Budurowycz, pp. 61–63; Mareș, pp. 64–87, 89–103, 110–112, 129, 273, 285–286, 291–292, 324–325, 331–333, 363, 372–379, 396–397, 434; Petrescu, pp. 343–346; Trașcă & Grad, pp. 187–192</ref> Confronted with Romania's argument that either Czechoslovak rule or an independent [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] were preferable to [[Hungarian irredentism]], Beck became convinced that Comnen was a "perfect imbecile", describing him as such in his memoirs.<ref>Budurowycz, p. 62</ref> Comnen obtained from him a promise that Poland would intervene to reduce Hungary's territorial demands, but Beck never acted on that pledge.<ref>Mareș, pp. 93–102, 301, 306, 309–310, 372–374, 395–405</ref> For his part, Comenen continued to aggravate the Poles by stating his support for an independent [[Ukraine]], which he argued would be a natural ally of Poland and Romania against both Germany and the Soviet Union.<ref>Mareș, p. 415</ref>
In parallel, Petrescu-Comnen worked with [[George Oprescu]] and [[Marie of Romania]], organizing the exhibit of German [[old master print]]s.<ref>Radu Moțoc, "O inițiere în istoria gravurii", in ''Confluențe Bibliologice'', Nr. 3–4/2009, p. 91</ref> Believing that France and Britain were not going to defend Romania,<ref>Petrescu, pp. 345–346; Prisăcaru, pp. 186–188</ref> he ultimately took Romania closer to Germany and the [[Axis Powers]]. From October 1938, he tried to persuade Germany not to dismantle [[Second Czechoslovak Republic|reduced Czechoslovakia]], and especially not to allow Hungary to annex Ruthenia. Despite assurances that Germany would only let Hungary take [[Hungarians in Ukraine|Hungarian areas]], the [[First Vienna Award]] produced a Hungarian [[Carpathian Ruthenia during World War II|Governorate of Subcarpathia]], which isolated Romania's territory.<ref>Trașcă & Grad, pp. 193–196</ref> This then opened the way for Hungarian demands in Transylvania. In November, Comnen suggested settling the Transylvanian issue through a [[population exchange]] with Hungary, noting that [[Hungarians in Romania|Romania's Hungarians]] were mostly town-dwellers. This proposal was rejected by demographer Béla Kenéz on the Hungarian side—he noted that it would have implied removing almost 2 million people to make room for the 16,000 [[Romanians in Hungary]].<ref>Kenéz, pp. 8–9</ref> Comnen also spearheaded a project to encourage the [[Fifth Aliyah|a mass emigration of Romanian Jews]], a draft of which was presented by [[Wilhelm Filderman]] and accepted on behalf of government by [[Mihai Ralea]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Aurel Vainer]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20160416040538/https://www.jewishfed.ro/downloads/realitatea/RE442-443.pdf "Contribuția evreimii române la Așezământul Muncii în Ereț Israel"], in ''[[Realitatea Evreiască]]'', Issues 442–443, January 2015, p. 7</ref>
===Downfall=== The change of policy toward Germany incensed the underground democratic opposition, and especially Maniu's [[National Peasants' Party]]. It accused Carol of appeasement and called for a national unity cabinet to deal with the crisis. In that context, Comnen had a publicized meeting with three former Ministers of Foreign Affairs ([[Dimitrie I. Ghika]], [[Victor Antonescu]], [[Istrate Micescu]]), showing that they backed his German rapprochement.<ref>Mareș, pp. 413–414</ref> The effort proved largely futile: as Comnen himself noted, Hitler resented Carol for repressing the Iron Guard and murdering its leader, [[Corneliu Zelea Codreanu]]; reportedly, this implicit criticism of the regime brought his demotion, by Carol, on December 20.<ref>Petrescu, p. 346</ref> However, Yugoslav diplomat Kosta St. Pavlowitch recalls that Carol had the idea to replace Comnen with [[Grigore Gafencu]], a journalist for ''[[Timpul]]'', when the three of them were in London; while there, Gafencu won the king's confidence.<ref>Pavlowitch, pp. 241–242</ref> Before Gafencu took over, Comnen was informed that he would return as Romania's representative to the Holy See.<ref>Vițalaru, pp. 351–352</ref> According to Pavlowitch, he had overall proven himself "a conscious bureaucrat and an astute diplomat, [...] but, as was reported, did not rise to the challenge of the events. [...] During the deepest of Europe's crises, [...] Romanian foreign politics had been entrusted to someone who had no means of influencing the events, and who looked on passively as the ground was slipping away from under his feet".<ref>Pavlowitch, p. 241</ref>
[[File:Pact of Neutral Countries, 1939 proposal.svg|thumb|340px|Petrescu-Comnen's proposed "Pact of Neutral Countries" (in gold)—[[Balkan Pact]] members, joined by [[Kingdom of Bulgaria|Bulgaria]] and protected by [[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]]. In black, the [[Axis Powers]]; [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] in blue and [[Soviet Union]] in red (1939 borders)]] Petrescu-Comnen took up his new office in Rome on January 20, 1939.<ref>Vițalaru, p. 352</ref> From his posting, he witnessed the revelations of a [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact|German–Soviet Pact]], which, as he reported to Gafencu, placed Romania in imminent danger.<ref>Georgeta Fodor, "Recenzii și note de lectură. ''România–Vatican. Relații Diplomatice, I, 1920–1950''", in ''Studia Universitatis Petru Maior. Series Historica'', Vol. 7, 2007, p. 331</ref> He remained in Rome after the outbreak of World War II a week later. The [[German invasion of Poland]] convinced Comnen that there was "no reasoning to be tried with the Germans"—a pessimisitic note which contrasted Gafencu's attempts to reach a new understanding with the Axis.<ref>Mareș, pp. 197–198</ref> According to his own recollections, he was entrusted by Gafencu and [[Şükrü Saracoğlu]] with obtaining Italian backing for the [[Balkan Pact]], which was to include a pacified Bulgaria; at the time, Italy was still "non-belligerent".<ref>Frank Marzari, "Projects for an Italian-Led Balkan Bloc of Neutrals, September–December 1939", in ''[[The Historical Journal]]'', Vol. 13, Issue 4, December 1970, pp. 767–788</ref> Although Mussolini eventually backed Hitler, Comen still hoped to obtain Italian and papal support for Romania before and during the [[Second Vienna Award]].<ref>Petrescu, pp. 346–347; Vițalaru, p. 352</ref> By April 1940, he was allegedly contacted by [[Myron Charles Taylor]], and through him informed US foreign policy.<ref>Brînzeu, p. 372</ref>
Hungary's annexation of [[Northern Transylvania]], preceded by the [[Soviet occupation of Bessarabia]], signaled a regime change in Romania. In September 1940, King Carol was ousted and an Axis-aligned [[National Legionary State|Iron Guard government]] took over in Bucharest; Petrescu-Comnen, identified as a pillar of the old system, was sacked within days.<ref>Petrescu, p. 347; Vițalaru, pp. 347, 353</ref> Effectively, his mission ended on November 15, 1940.<ref>Vițalaru, p. 353</ref> Following the [[Legionnaires' rebellion and Bucharest pogrom|civil war of January 1941]], which Petrescu-Comnen described as Romania's "black days",<ref>Petrescu, p. 347</ref> the Guardist regime was replaced, and [[Ion Antonescu]] governed alone. From his new home in [[Merano]], Comnen petitioned the ministry, insisting that he could still prove useful in his dealings with the Holy See, and through it prevent the [[Magyarization]] of Northern Transylvania. He found a backer in the government secretary, Alexandru Cretzianu,<ref>Petrescu, pp. 347–348</ref> but was denied full reemployment. He was ultimately pensioned on May 1, 1941.<ref>Mareș, p. 356; Petrescu, p. 348; Potra, p. 608; Vițalaru, p. 347</ref>
===In Florence=== Like many other diplomats who favored the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]], Comnen decided not to return home as Antonescu sealed Romania's alliance with the Axis.<ref>Vițalaru, p. 347</ref> Instead, he was co-opted by [[Viorel Tilea]] on London's [[Romanian National Committee]] (RNC)—alongside Gafencu, [[Dimitrie Dimăncescu]], and [[Ioan Pangal]].<ref>Petraru, pp. 127–128</ref> Settled in [[Florence]], he led an [[International Red Cross]] Committee, and founded an exile section of the [[Romanian Red Cross]].<ref>Petrescu, p. 348; Potra, p. 608</ref> In 1943, after the [[Allied invasion of Italy]], he mediated between the two sides to preserve the city's art and architecture from destruction, and in return was awarded the title of honorary citizen of Florence.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 348–349, 353</ref> That year, he published in Geneva the book ''Anarchie, dictature ou l'organisation internationale'' ("Anarchy, Dictatorship or International Organization").<ref>Petrescu, p. 351; Vițalaru, p. 348</ref>
Choosing to remain in exile to Italy after the [[Soviet occupation of Romania]], Petrescu-Comnen spoke out against [[communization]] and lectured in particular against the [[Danubian Confederation]] project; nevertheless, he intervened to mitigate the effects of drought and famine in his native country.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 349–350</ref> By 1947, he was also collecting and publishing in Florence his records of the war, and of his own part in it, as ''Preludi del grande dramma'' ("Preludes of the Great Tragedy"), followed in 1949 by the more detailed ''I Responsabili'' ("The Culprits"), at [[Mondadori]]. In exile, he resumed contacts with Carol, who stated his appreciation for the diplomat and described ''Preludi'' as the best analysis of Romania's plight in the late interwar.<ref>Pavlowitch, p. 241</ref> The books were also reviewed by the historian [[Carlile Aylmer Macartney]], who also found ''Preludi'' to be the better work: in ''I Responsabili'', he argued, the "butter is spread more thinly", including "a general account of European developments in which M. Comnène had himself no hand, and for which he uses sources which are generally available". According to Macartney, the books show Comnen as "well informed, intelligent, and right-minded", his "sketches of various personalities" displaying "elegance and ''esprit''."<ref>[[Carlile Aylmer Macartney]], "Reviews of Books. Second World War and Its Origins. ''Preludi del grande dramma'', by N. P. Comnène; ''I Responsabili'', by N. P. Comnène", in ''[[International Affairs (journal)|International Affairs]]'', Vol. 26, Issue 2, 1950, pp. 234–235</ref>
Comnen's hope of returning to Romania was curbed by the establishment of a [[Communist Romania|Communist regime]]. He joined Gafencu in cooperating with the [[European Movement International]] (also advancing a [[United States of Europe|European federation]] in his various articles and books), while also maintaining links with the RNC, now an anti-communist organization, building bridges between the latter and the Holy See.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 350–352</ref> In 1950, he intervened as a mediator Gafencu and the RNC leader, [[Nicolae Rădescu]].<ref>Petrescu, pp. 350–351</ref> The following year, [[Constantin Vișoianu]] nominated him as RNC representative to the Vatican,<ref>Petraru, p. 156</ref> although he was eventually assigned, that same year, to represent the RNC in the Italian republic.<ref>Potra, p. 608</ref>
Comnen was also taking trips to Brazil, initially as a delegate of Florence city council.<ref>Petrescu, p. 352</ref> In September 1954, he was at [[Rio de Janeiro]], lecturing at the Romanian House on issues of international diplomacy.<ref>Ático Vilas-Boas da Mota, "Casa Română din Rio de Janeiro sau 'Tărâmul nostalgiei'", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', February 2001, p. 39</ref> He resumed his publishing in 1957, with the memoirs of his 1919 trip to Hungary (published by a Romanian group in [[Madrid]]) and the historical review ''Luci e ombre sull'Europa'' ("Lights and Shadows over Europe").<ref>Petrescu, p. 352</ref> By then, his Bucharest townhouse, located within walking distance of [[Victory Square, Bucharest|Victory Square]], had been confiscated by the communist regime together with his ''[[objets d'art]]'' and his antique book collection.<ref name="apcasă"/> His family was also exposed to persecution: nephew Dan Cernovodeanu was sent to a labor camp on the [[Danube–Black Sea Canal]]; while there, he conspired with fellow inmate Ion Mitucă. In 1955, the latter, who was planning an anti-communist insurgency, tried to defect and contact Comnen.<ref name="mdsbm99–100"/>
The former minister died in his adoptive Florence, without completing work on his final volume, a diplomatic history of Romania.<ref>Petrescu, p. 352</ref> In addition to receiving the Olympic Cross and the Order of Saint George knighthood, he had been a Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Star of Romania]], a Grand Cross of the [[Order For Merit]], an Officer of the [[Order of the Crown (Romania)|Order of the Crown]], a Commander of the Order of the Cross of Marie; a Grand Cross of the ''[[Pour le Mérite]]'', the [[Order of the German Eagle|German Eagle]], the [[Saxe-Ernestine House Order]], the [[Order of George I]], the [[Order of the Crown of Italy]], and the [[Order of the Yugoslav Crown]]; as well as Commander of the [[Order of the Redeemer]] and the ''[[Order of Polonia Restituta|Polonia Restituta]]'', an Officer of the [[Order of the Oak Crown|Oak Crown]], a Knight of the ''[[Ordre des Palmes Académiques]]'' and the [[House Order of Hohenzollern]], and a recipient of [[Benemerenti medal]].<ref>Petrescu, p. 354</ref> He was survived by daughter Elsa-Irène, known after marriage as Irene Bie, who lived in [[Maryhill, Washington]] and donated her collection of Romanian paintings to the local art gallery, named after her father;<ref name="mhill"/> and by daughter-in-law Angela Comnène. The latter published in 1982 an English biography of Comnen, and did research into his genealogy.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 331–332</ref>
[[Censorship in Communist Romania|Communist censorship]] meant that Comnen's contribution was unmentioned in Romania until the 1970s, when his work was briefly covered, with some excerpts, detailing his anti-Nazism, appearing in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'' in the early 1980s; his memory was primarily maintained by his peers in Italy.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 352–354</ref> Following the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]], he was again the subject of public scrutiny: his ''Notes sur la guerre roumaine'' was translated and published by [[Polirom]] in 1995; and his decorations, donated to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs by Angela Comnène, went on public display in 1998.<ref>Petrescu, pp. 353–354</ref> In 2003, his documents relating to the Holy See were published as part of an [[Editura Enciclopedică]] series, with a preface by [[Jean-Claude Périsset]].<ref>Vițalaru, p. 354</ref> The Comnen house, heavily damaged during the [[1977 Vrancea earthquake]], was inscribed into the [[National Register of Historic Monuments in Romania]]. However, by 2011 it had fallen into disrepair and was threatened with demolition.<ref name="apcasă"/>

[[Iron Cross, II class]] (1917/) | spouse = | relations = | signature = | website = | other_name = | memorials = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | module = }} '''Nikola Dimitrov Nedeva''' (1886–1970) was a [[Bulgaria]]n [[Major general]], [[politician]] and [[Military history|military historian]]. He was the Minister of Interior affairs and Public Health in the third and fourth cabinets of [[Georgi Kyoseivanov]] (November 1938 to February 1940). His first cousins were Lieutenant General [[Nikola Mihov]] and Major General Ivan Ivanov - descendants of the great Mollov’s family. Nedev was a friend of Petar Danov (also known by the name Beinsa Douno, and often called Master by his followers) who was a Bulgarian philosopher and spiritual teacher of the [[Universal White Brotherhood]]. Nedev was a follower of the Danov's teachings. ==Biography== ===Early years=== Nikola Nedev was born on the 7 July 1886 (20 July 1886 - new style) in [[Veliko Tarnovo]], Bulgaria into a family of intellectuals. After graduating from high school, he continued his education at the Higher Military School. ===Career=== On the 15 August 1907 Cadet Nedev graduated with excellence from the artillery class of the Higher Military School. As Second Lieutenant he began his career as platoon commander of the 5th artillery regiment in [[Shumen|Shoumen]], and on 1 January 1908, Second Lieutenant Nedev was promoted to platoon commander of the [[Sofia]] fortress battalion. During his career as an officer, Nikola Nedev was promoted to the following ranks: Lieutenant, 4 September 1910, Captain 1 November 1913, Major 1 January 1918, Lieutenant Colonel 30 January 1923, Colonel 26 March 1928, and Major General 6 June 1935. In 1936 he retired from the army. In 1911 Nedev was awarded an excellent mark in the entrance exam at the Higher Military Academy ''Еcole de guerre'' in Brussels, Belgium. During that time he served in the artillery arsenal and the coastguard. The same year, he married Tzvetanka Grozdanova (1892-1984). They had two children—daughter Rousska Nedev Koutzouglou (1915-2010), and son Dimitar Nedev (1916-1980). ====Participation in the Balkan War==== The war began after the [[Albania during the Balkan Wars|controversy]] between the allied Balkan countries Bulgaria, [[Serbia]], [[Montenegro]], [[Greece]] and the [[Ottoman Empire]] could not be resolved by political and diplomatic means. From 17 September 1912, the Bulgarian army mobilized about 600,000 people and 700 guns. The mobilized army of Serbia, Montenegro and Greece totaled 295,000 people and 648 guns. Many artists, sculptors, writers and actors joined the Bulgarian army as volunteers. Part of it was merged with 14,760 troops from Macedonia and Eastern [[Thrace]]. The Balkan war began on 5 October 1912. Captain Nedev was the commander of the 3rd battery of slight siege department of the Sofia fortress battalion. This artillery regiment was part of the [[Second Bulgarian Army]], which besieged [[Edirne]] fortress whose defender was the "Feric" (Iron) Mehmed Shukri Pasha. The commanders of the Second Bulgarian Army– Lieutenant General [[Nikola Ivanov]], Major General George Vazov, Colonel [[Nikola Zhekov]], Major [[Ivan Valkov]], and the commander of the First Bulgarian Army Lieutenant General Basil Koutinchev, considered that an open assault against Edirne would be the successful tactic. The chief commanders, General [[Mihail Savov]], General [[Ivan Fichev]], and General [[Radko Dimitriev]], believed the town would be forced to surrender from the effects of the resulting famine. The Bulgarian and Serbian army, commanded by Major General Vladimir Vazov, carried out this tactic between 11–13 March 1913. Colonel Nedev was General Vazov’s adjutant. The tacti was successful and on the 13 March 1913 the Edirne fortress capitulated; Shukri Pasha was imprisoned. This was one of the happy and unique moment for Nikola Nedev and the Bulgarian soldiers during the Balkan war. There were many articles in the world press about the success of the Bulgarian army, and especially its military tactics. ====To Brussels and back==== After the war Nedev returned to Brussels to continue his education. When the [[World War I|Great War]] began, he returned to Bulgaria and was chosen to be the battery commander in the [[Shumen fortress]] battalion. In the spring of 1915 he was appointed as vice chairman of the new Military Historical Commission to the Staff of the Army. ====The First World War==== World War I began in 1914 between the [[Allies of World War I|Entente]] (France, Great Britain, Russian Empire, Serbia), and the Triple Alliance (Germany, [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungary]], Ottoman Empire) and from 14 October 1915, Bulgaria. The war ended on 11 November 1918 with the capitulation of the Triple Alliance. On the 23 September 1915 the mobilization in Bulgaria began. On 14 October 1915 Bulgaria declared war against Serbia. Bulgaria kept fighting with the French and English army in Macedonia throughout the entire war. The war between Bulgaria and the Romanian Kingdom and her ally the Russian Empire began on the 1 September 1916. Bulgaria surrendered on 29 September 1918. [[Treaty of Neuilly-sur-Seine|The Neuilly Peace Treaty]] was signed on the 27 November 1919, and ratified on the 9 August 1920. 105,000 Bulgarian soldiers were killed, 150,000 were wounded, and 60,000 were disabled. Financial and physical losses amounted to 7 billion [[leva]], economic losses and debts equaled 100 billion [[leva]]. In September 1915 Captain Nedev was appointed procurement officer on the staff of the 8th Division in [[Stara Zagora]]. During the war he served at the division's headquarters. In the battles for [[Tutrakan]] he was the battery commander. In July 1916 he was the commander of the new howitzer battery, part of the 2nd heavy artillery regiment, fighting in [[Dobruja|Dobrudja]]. In 1917 Captain Nedev was the operational head of section to the staff of the army. As adjutant in the 9th Pleven’s infantry division he fought at the military positions for [[Dojran]] until the end of the war in 1918. ====After the First World War==== On 16 June 1919 Major Nedev was appointed as vice-chairman of the historical department to the staff of the army. This post was very close to his calling; at this point he collected the historical material for the books he would later write. At the beginning of 1920 Nedev was the cabinet’s delegated military representative to the Occupying Commission in Bulgaria. Its task was to control the provisions of the [[Treaty of Neuilly-sur-Seine|Neuilly Peace Treaty]], defining the territory, borders, reparations, and demilitarization. The government chose Nedev for his reputation as a truly loyal, brave, military patriot, fluent French, Italian and German. Thanks to his tact and diplomatic skills, and granted favorable conditions, he managed to negotiate a small territorial benefit; the southern border was moved a few kilometers into Greece’s territory. In 1922 Nedev along with those who had not graduated from the Higher Military Schools in [[Saint Petersburg]] defended his doctoral thesis and was declared graduated from the ''Ecole de guerre''. In the same year he was appointed to the headquarters of the army and lectured on military history in the Sofia Military School. Between 25 August 1923 and 13 September 1924 Lieutenant Colonel Nedev was the commander of the 18th Infantry Battalion in [[Veliko Tarnovo]]. In September 1924 he was commander of the tactical training on the staff of the 1st Infantry Battalion in Sofia. and in 1927 he became chief of staff. From 1925 until 1928 Lieutenant Colonel Nedev was the head of the Military Intelligence in Bulgaria. ====Literary activity==== While defending [[Dojran]], Nedev came up with the idea to record the bravery of the Bulgarian soldiers of Pleven’s regiment. In 1921 he wrote the book ''The Dojran epic – 1915-1918''. It tells of the victory of Plevan's 9th infantry division, commanded by Major General [[Vladimir Vazov]]. The army fought on the southern front from 1915 to 1918 against French, English, Serbian, Russian and Greek soldiers. The book presents a number of battles, including that of 16 June 1917 between the 9th Pleven’s infantry division and the 22nd, 26th, and 30th English divisions. The English army advanced with 160 cannons, 11 mortars and 440 guns. Over the course of four days the British fired over 100,000 shells, but the results on their side were disappointing, keeping them from further advancement. The Bulgarian offence was so effective that the enemy’s army suffered heavy casualties. In 1927 Nedev published his second book ''Bulgaria in the World War – 1915-1918'' a historical review, dedicated to "those who would continue the deeds of the whole Bulgarian nation". It book was reissued in 2001. In 1928 Nedev published the book ''The Liberation of Sofia'' a review of this unusual military operation in the winter of 1877. In 1929 Nedev published his fourth book ''The Wars of Liberation – 1877-1878, 1885, 1912-1913, 1915-1918'', where he wrote a thorough review of the wars of the third Bulgarian Kingdom. [[File:Nikola Nedev young.jpg|thumb|241x241px]] ====Military attache in Rome, Ankara and Athens==== In 1930, Nedev was commander of the Juncer battalion of the Higher Military School. The same year he was nominated as [[military attache]] in Rome, Ankara and Athens (the headquarters were in Rome). He discovered that the Ottoman Empire had sold its barred record. Nedev knew that it contained very important documents about Bulgaria’s history. This archive was bought by the Bulgarian government following Nedev’s advice. Thus Levsky’s case (the most celebrated national hero) was brought back to Bulgaria. After his return from Rome in 1932 Nikola Nedev was appointed commander of the 14th Macedonian Infantry Regiment in [[Blagoevgrad|Gorna Dzhumaya]]. In 1934 he was commander of the 8th Infantry Division in Stara Zagora. There, on 6 May 1936, he was promoted to the rank of major general. At the time in the 12th Infantry Regiment in Stara Zagora, forty young soldiers were accused of communist activity. The Judge Advocate demanded that they be sentenced to death. Nedev stood by his men and said that he as general, would die with his soldiers, showing the world that people could be sentenced to death for their beliefs. The punishment was cancelled. At the end of 1935 General Nedev was commander of Pleven’s Garrison. He also led the 4th Military engineering group in Pleven. At the end of 1936 he retired from the army. He was appointed chairman of the Military History Commission, as well as chairman of the cycling Union. At this point he had a chance to collect documents for his future books. ====Minister in Kyoseivanov's cabinets==== From 14 November 1938 Nedev was Minister of Interior Affairs and Public Health in the cabinet of [[Georgi Kyoseivanov]]. He held this office from 23 October 1939 until 15 October 1940. In November 1936, Germany, Italy and Japan signed a treaty agreeing to a common foreign policy. On 11 March 1938 Germany occupied Austria. On 30 September 1939 Germany occupied [[Sudetenland|Sudeteland]],and six months later she invaded Czechoslovakia. In 1939 Italy occupied Albania. On 23 August the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact|Ribentrop-Molotov Treaty]] was signed. Poland was divided between Germany and the USSR, and on the 1st of September WWII began. Bulgarian society was divided in two parts; those supporting Great Britain, France and USA, and those supporting Germany, Italy and Japan. The cabinet of Georgi Kyoseivanov remained neutral until 15 September. On 31 July 1938 Bulgaria signed the [[Balkan Pact|Balkan pact]] – its neighbors gave up the military restrictions of the Neuilly Treaty. [[Boris III of Bulgaria|Tsar Boris III]] disbanded Parliament. At Hitler’s insistence, Bulgaria began its [[Holocaust in Bulgaria|genocide of Jews]] in 1939. Nedev twice requested an audience with Tsar Boris III and insisted that no Jewish men who risked their lives for Bulgaria’s freedom be sentenced to death. Thanks to his efforts a sailing vessel transporting Jews was not sunk in the Black sea. Nikola Nedev was procurator of the Takvorian Tobacco Company for a year from 1 July 1941. ====After World War II==== After World War II, the new political forces in Bulgaria determined Major General Nikola Nedev to be a patriot and a humanist who typified the feats of the Bulgarian army. Despite that assessment, the communist government arrested him in 1951. His family was not informed of his whereabouts for four months. Nedev was held in a concentration camp along with the members of Bulgaria’s intelligencia – politicians, senior members of the military, ministers, and intellectuals. In 1954 he was released after three years of hard labor and deprived of his title and pension. Nedev kept his dignity; he thanked God he was alive, and forgave the communists "as they did not know what they had been doing". ==Awards== - Erinnerungskreuz für die Unabhängigkeit Bulgariens - 1910 - Order of Bravery IV grade, 1st Class - 1917 - Order of Military Merit, II Grade - Order of St Alexander - Iron Cross, II Class - 1917 ==Writings== - 1921 - ''The Dojran epic – 1915-1918'' - 1927 - ''Bulgaria in the World War – 1915-1918'' - 1928 - ''The Liberation of Sofia'' - 1929 - ''The Wars of Liberation – 1877-1878, 1885, 1912-1913, 1915-1918'' ==Sources== - Private archive of Nikola Nedev, Veliko Tarnovo - Memoir by Rousska Nikolova Nedeva-Koutzouglou - daughter of Nikola Nedev - Prof., Dr. Dimitar Kolev, memoir - Archives of the Ministry of Interior Affairs {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nedev, Nikola}} [[Category:1970 deaths]] [[Category:1886 births]] [[Category:20th-century Bulgarian politicians]] [[Category:Bulgarian generals]] [[Category:Bulgarian historians]] [[Category:Bulgarian military personnel of the Balkan Wars]] [[Category:Bulgarian military personnel of World War I]]
